Subjective: Back pain radiating down right leg, thigh, and lower leg to foot; worsened over 1.5 weeks; constant discomfort; unable to sleep; tried paracetamol and ibuprofen with no relief; stopped working due to pain; some tingling; decreased sensation on outside of lower leg; no fever, no headache, no cough, no shortness of breath; no smoking/alcohol; Request: Wants pain relief and to return to work.
Objective: BP: not recorded; HR: not recorded; RR: not recorded; T: not recorded; Physical exam: normal strength in legs; decreased sensation on outside of lower leg; normal reflexes; no unusual findings on back or legs.
Assessment: Lumbosacral radicular syndrome, suspected herniated nucleus pulposus (HNP); no signs of cauda equina syndrome.
Plan: Pain relief: pregabalin, start with low dose and titrate up as needed
Physiotherapy to improve back flexibility and reduce nerve compression
Follow-up telephone appointment in 1 week to assess pain relief
Safety netting: contact doctor or GP out-of-hours service if symptoms worsen, including loss of sensation in 'riding breeches area', inability to urinate or defecate, or significant weakness in leg
No immediate need for CT scan or MRI; may consider referral for surgery if conservative management fails
